content.description: As Manny and I were setting up an anchor to get to the top of Visions of Yesteryears, I was taking in the amazing views of the canyon and saw for the first time the Indian ruins that were the home of a people long ago. I let my mind wander for a short time of what it must have been like to live in this beautiful area and what it must have been like to have sat out side their home and watch the falls and the sun set on the pine covered mountains. I felt like for a moment that I had just bonded with a people blessed to have called this beautiful area home.
content.protection: small to large gear with bolted anchors
content.location: The route is the obvious left trending corner crack on south side of the falls. It has three very distint cruxes. The first is thin hands off the ground. The second is an overhanging stemming section, and the last gaurds the finish in a short right facing dihedral.

content.description:
Crux is the starting moves. 4 well protected bolts on the face. 

  Not sure who put this "mini route" up, but we used it this last weekend (Oct 2017) to set up a Top Rope from the top bolt (4th Bolt) to teach Basic Rock Climbing Skills.  The Bolts are SOLID and easy to clip on the move.  I went above initially to look for bolts on top to set up an anchor and there are none.  If you want to set an anchor on the ledge (the wall going up behind the climb) bring Cams, Hexes, Large Nuts and a good length of Cordelette...  It's dirty cracks, but could be made bomber real easy. 

  You could set some cams up back from the ledge (10+ feet) in the crack of the next wall if you wanted too to belay a second up this little route, or a top rope, but then you would be dealing with your rope constantly being being rubbed over an edge and dragging dirt down on top of you.
content.protection: Four Quick Draws,  Cams/Nuts to build and anchor to belay a second, or just go sit way back from the edge and take your chances....  NO FIXED anchors on top to build a belay from...
content.location: About 50yrs beyond the bridge (going up the mountain towards the falls) look on the wall to the left for tab painted bolts.  First one is about 8 ft off of the ground.  If you top out, walk off to your right and you can either sling your rope around a large oak about 100 yrds up and rap or down climb the 4-5th class or go up another 100 or so and walk down a more defined draw.

content.description: The first crux is moving past the second and third bolts. There is another crux at the roof at the sixth bolt.
content.location: Left of the waterfall. Second bolted line to the right of Arron's "Family Ties."

climbs.name: Two in a Toyota Smiling
climbs.fa: Aaron Collins, William Bester, John Biskup

content.description: Two in a Toyota Smiling  requires 14 Draws to do in 2 pitches or 20 to get it in a single push. It  starts in the far left corner and shares the first bolt of All My Friends and finishes next to a 200' year round waterfall. What else needs to be said. Climb it and you'll never forget it.

climbs.name: Thin Red Line
climbs.fa: Aaron Collins, Logan Johnson, Porter Collins, Dax Collins,

content.description:
Climbs the broken rock just left of a slabby section then on to vertical rock to a shelf. Continue following bolts up and left of a small roof and into dihedral to the anchors.

 My adult belayer went home the night before so  I was left with my sons 5, 7, and my 200lb 13 year old nephew. Of course I did what any self respecting route developer would do and made a harness out of a red 7mm cordelette, tought him how to use a grigri and commenced a full out assault of the wall.  I did  have some compassion on my belayer and broke it up into 2 parts. After i was done my nephew asked if my harness cut into my legs too. I told him they are called groin pains... and no im used to it. Not sure if he's gonna help me do another route.lol
content.location: Right wall of a short slot canyon just before the bridge 200 yards from the falls.

content.description: The crux is moving past the first roof (second bolt). There is a redpoint crux up higher on the route. The route does wanter a bit on mostly good rock.
content.protection: Eleven bolts, drop-in anchors. Well protected.
content.location: Left of the waterfall. Fourth bolted route from climbers left, right of Aarons 5.7 (Family Ties). Starts in the shade under a large roof that sits about 12 feet off the ground.

content.description: Follows right leaning crack til it ends about 30'. Step left and follow crack to the top. Anchors to be added soon.
content.location: Left shoulder of the wall before you can see the falls. A small tree is at the base of the climb.

climbs.name: Handsome Princess
climbs.fa: Aaron Collins, Shi-Ann Scott, Sue Rutherford, Scott Duemler, Clay Lippincott, John Biskup, Janina, Natasha, Matt

content.description: 10 bolts, steep start to long bulgy slab.
content.location: Just around the corner from a huge overhanging dehidral (Visions of Yesteryears). First bolt is 10 feet off the deck. The route climbs through a steep right facing dihedral and continues up a somewhat slabby face right of a deep and bush covered crack.

climbs.name: Family Ties
climbs.fa: Aaron Collins, Colten Kolenborn, Porter Collins, Dax Collins, Logan Johnson

content.description: There is a cruxy section getting out of the left facing corner and a cruxy section at the top where it gets steep.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 2 bolts with rap rings
content.location: Starts in an open book with 3 bolts just as you are dropping into the canyon from the road.

content.description: Start just right of the roof. Go up and left until you hit the crux dihedral, then continue through easier but still engaging climbing to the chains. Turn around and enjoy the view!
content.location: South (far) side of the waterfall, right around the corner from the unmissable overhanging dihedral of Visions of Yesteryears.

climbs.name: All My Friends
climbs.fa: Eliot Metsger, A. Collins, M. Rangel

content.description: Getting thru the final roof/overhang is the crux.
content.location: Left side of Falls in the corner

content.description: Workman falls sits just west of the Sierra Ancha Wilderness and to the north of Roosevelt Lake. The rock near the falls is bullet hard quartzite of sorts that forms a westward facing horseshoe. Most of the rock is on the south side and faces north, making it a great summer area.
